editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: HIS MAIESTIES RESOLUTION Concerning the Setting up of His Standard at Nottingham on Monday next. Signified to both Houses of PARLIAMENT, August 17.
Wherein is likewise Declared, the Number of His Majesties Army, both of Horse and Feot.
Together with four Propositions, presented to the House of Commons, from the Gentry of Yorke-shire, upon Wednesday, being the 17. day of this instant month of August, 1642.

p.hi: Ordered that this be forthwith printed and published

div.p: LONDON: Printed for J. Hansott. August 18. 1642.

div.head: An Exact RELATION OF HIS MAJESTIES RESOLUTION to set up his Standard at Nottingham on Monday next.
div.p:
VPon Saterday last, being the 12 Day of this instant month of August, his Majesty set forth another Proclamation wherin he expresseth his Royall intention to set up his Standard on Monday ne • t in some convenient place which His Majestie shall make choise of, commanding all his loving Subjects, that will aid and assist him, to repair thither; proclaiming
all those that shall refuse to obey the Commission of Array to be Traytors, and using many great threatning words against them; and doth thereby appoint and ordain the Earl of Cumberland Generall, for the rainng of Forces both of Horse and Foot in the Northe •• Parts.

Wherupon divers Gentlemen of good quality, being well affected to the King and Parliament, assembled themselves together in Yorke-shire aforesaid, and thought fit to send the Proclamation with a full Relation of the State of the Countrey to the Parliament.
Therupon they framed a Letter, and inclosed the Proclamation therein, and • e • t it away Post.
Which Letter was read in the House on Wednesday els • 17. of this instant mo • th of August; the effect whereof amongst div • rs other things, was as followeth, viz.

That His Majesties Army doth not consist of above four thousand Horse and Foot, and many of the Horses very unserviceable, and the men the very • umme of the Countrey, being for the greatest leud and idle persons, that were gathered up and down the Countreyes, by beating of Drummes; And that a great part of the Trayned Bands of that County, that refused to serve themselves, or lend their Arms; had them violently taken from them by the Cavaleers, who had plundred many great Houses of that County, breaking open Trunks, Chests, and taking all that th • y could find therein, with many more Out-rages, and inhumane Acts, which they daily commit against those that stands well affected to the Parliament. They have also plundered Sir Philip Stapletons house, and Mr. Marwoods.

But on Wednesday last, his Goods and Plate being taken from him, and threatned to kill hi • wife, to make her confesse where her husband was, saying, they would kill all such Puritane Round heads, &c.
Wherupon the said Gentlemen thought good to present certain propositions to the Parliament, for the good and safety of their Country and Estates, which were to this effect, viz.

I. That the Parliament would bee pleased to make an Order that the Cavaleers should not plunder and spoile men of their Goods, and in case they should be plundered, and robbed thereof, that preparatton might bee made unto them.
II. That such a Number of Armes and Ammunition might be sent unto Hull, that a sufficient store might be kept there, for the safetie and defence of that County.

III. That a considerable Number of Horse and Foot may be sent down into those parts, and
that such persons whose Names were presented to the House, should be made Commanders and have power for the raising of Forces, wherby they may be able to defend themselves and their County, &c.

IV. That there may be constant Recourse, between the Parliament, and that country, by some Persons imployed f ••• the carrying of Letters too and fro that s •
••• y may more frequently understand the pleasure and proceedings of Parliamen • , which in re • ard of the remotenesse o • the place, ot ••• wise • hey cannot doe.

They also signified to the House, that they had intelligence, th •
〈◊〉 Majesty intended to set up h •• Standard at Nottingham, or neer therabout, 〈◊〉 that His Majesty intended to go f • o •
Yorke on Tuesday next, being 〈◊〉 sixt ••• th of August.
